definition: A female maker of, or dealer in, articles of fashion,especially of the fashionable dress of ladies; a woman who givesdirection to the style or mode of dress.
A person who keeps a house of prostitution, or procures womenfor a lewd purpose; a procurer or procuress; a lewd person; --usually applied to a woman.
A child's cap; a hood, or something worn on the head.An old woman's biggin for a nightcap. Massinger.
The wife or the widow of a marquis; a woman who has the rankand dignity of a marquis. Spelman.
A woman who instructs; a preceptress; a governess. Johnson.
A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said todevour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; awith.
The quality of being feminine; womanliness; womanishness.
The wife of a peer; a woman ennobled in her own right, or byright of marriage.
A woman who betrays her country or any trust; a traitoress.Dryden.

A term of address implying inferiority and used in anger,contempt, reproach, or disrespectful familiarity, addressed to a manor boy, but sometimes to a woman. In sililoquies often preceded byah. Not used in the plural. "Ah, sirrah mistress." Beau & Fl.Go, sirrah, to my cell. Shak.
Like a woman; womanly.Womanlike, taking revenge too deep. Tennyson.
The possession by a woman of only one husband at the same time;-- contrasted with polyandry.
A knavish woman. Carlyle.
Government by a woman. Chesterfield.
The state of a woman bringing forth a child, or being in labor;parturition.
A woman supposed to be endowed with a spirit of prophecy.
A city woman [R.]
A woman who ascends or flies in an aircraft.
A woman who does needlework; a seamstress.
A woman guilty of fornication. Shak.
The adoration or worship of woman.The sentimental gyneolatry of chivalry, which was at best but skin-deep. Lowell.
A woman who is a treasurer. [R.]
A knitted worsted jacket, worn over the waist of a woman'sdress.
A female Moor; a Moorish woman.
A woman who is a slave, or in bondage.He who was of the bondwoman. Gal. iv. 23.
A woman who negotiates. Miss Edgeworth.
Government by a woman, female power; gyneocracy. Bailey.
A woman who plays in tragedy.
A plaited or gathered flounce on a woman's garment.
A Hebrew woman.
A woman chauffeur.
A woman who is a prelate; the wife of a prelate. Milton.

A custom, among certain barbarous tribes, that when a womangives birth to a child her husband takes to his bed, as if ill.The world-wide custom of the couvade, where at childbirth the husbandundergoes medical treatment, in many cases being put to bed for days.Tylor.
A female demon or fiend. See Succubus.Though seeming in shape a woman natural Was a fiend of the kind thatsuccubæ some call. Mir. for Mag.
A woman who bears a child for the first time.
A black woman; a female negro.

A subclass of Mammalia, having a cloaca in which the ducts ofthe urinary, genital, and alimentary systems terminate, as in birds.The female lays eggs like a bird. See Duck mole, under Duck, andEchidna.
Derived from the name of one's mother, or other femaleancestor; as, a metronymic name or appellation.-- A metronymic appellation.
A female disciple. [Obs.]
A female monarch. [Obs.]

The strawberry finch, a small Indian song bird (Estreldaamandava), commonly caged and kept for fighting. The female is olivebrown; the male, in summer, mostly crimson; -- called also redwaxbill. [Written also amaduvad and avadavat.]
A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled topreside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, orfountain.
The external organs of generation, especially of the female;the vulva.
A female slave, or one bound to service without wages, asdistinguished from a hired servant.
Having a medium compass between the soprano and contralto; --said of the voice of a female singer.-- n.(a) A mezzo-soprano voice.(b) A person having such a voice.
The principal female divinity of the Phoenicians, as Baal wasthe principal male divinity. W. Smith.
A female procurer, or pander.

A large South African antelope (Strepsiceros kudu). The maleshave graceful spiral horns, sometimes four feet long. The generalcolor is reddish or grayish brown, with eight or nine white bands oneach side, and a pale dorsal stripe. The old males become dark bluishgray, due to the skin showing through the hair. The females arehornless. Called also nellut. [Written also kudu.]
The male of the European black grouse (Tetrao tetrix, Linn.); -- so called by sportsmen. The female is called gray hen. See Heathgrouse.
A female servant whose business is the care of the dairy.

A subclass of Mammalia, including nearly all the mammals ofAustralia and the adjacent islands, together with the opossums ofAmerica. They differ from ordinary mammals in having the corpuscallosum very small, in being implacental, and in having their youngborn while very immature. The female generally carries the young forsome time after birth in an external pouch, or marsupium. Called alsoMarsupiata.
A female native or resident of Paris.
(Arch.) A draped female figure supporting an entablature, inthe place of a column or pilaster.

A small, slender nematoid worm (Trichina spiralis) which, inthe larval state, is parasitic, often in immense numbers, in thevoluntary muscles of man, the hog, and many other animals. Wheninsufficiently cooked meat containing the larvæ is swallowed by man,they are liberated and rapidly become adult, pair, and theovoviviparous females produce in a short time large numbers of youngwhich find their way into the muscles, either directly, or indirectlyby means of the blood. Their presence in the muscles and theintestines in large numbers produces trichinosis.
A dangerous whirlpool on the coast of Sicily opposite Scylla onthe Italian coast. It is personified as a female monster. See Scylla.
A female relative. Shak.
One of a class of fabled female water spirits who might receivea human soul by intermarrying with a mortal.
The pistillidium or female organ in the higher cryptogamicplants, corresponding to the pistil in flowering plants.
One of the two bodies or nuclei (called male and femalepronuclei) which unite to form the first segmentation nucleus of animpregnated ovum.
A female or hen eagle. [R.] Sherwood.
A female worshiper of idols.

The act by which, either in animals or plants, materialprepared by the generative organs the female organism is brought incontact with matter from the organs of the male, so that a neworganism results; impregnation; fertilization.
A plain cap or headdress for women or girls; especially, onetying under the chin by a very broad band, generally of the samematerial as the cap itself. Thackeray.
The monthly courses of women; menstrual discharges; menses.

A porch or waiting room, usually at the west end of an abbeychurch, where the monks collected on returning from processions,where bodies were laid previous to interment, and where women wereallowed to see the monks to whom they were related, or to hear divineservice. Also, frequently applied to the porch of a church, as at Elyand Durham cathedrals. Gwilt.
An ornamental covering for the breast, worn originally both bymen and women. Those worn by women were often richly decorated.A stately lady in a diamond stomacher. Johnson.
Having the appearance of that which is seen in pictures byAntoine Watteau, a French painter of the eighteenth century; --saidesp. of women's garments; as, a Watteau bodice.
A light fabric of wool, worn on the head by women; a cloud.
A garment varying in form and use at different times, and worndoth by men and women.Wearing her Norman car, and her kirtle of blue. Longfellow.
A man who assists women in childbirth; a man midwife; anobstetrician.
A kind of drum, tabor, or tabret, in use from the highestantiquity.Miriam . . . took a timbrel in her hand, and all the women went outafter her with timbrels and with dances. Ex. xv. 20.
An outer garment for men or women, originally of fur, or linedwith fur; a lady's outer garment, made of silk or other fabric.
A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings,and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns,both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
Fondness for women; uxoriousness; -- opposed to Ant: misogyny.[R.] Byron.
A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neckand throat, and extending to the shoulders.
Made by a tailor or according to a tailor's fashion; -- saidspecif. of women's garments made with certain closeness of fit,simplicity of ornament, etc.
The act of objurgating; reproof.While the good lady was bestowing this objurgation on Mr.Ben Allen.Dickens.With a strong objurgation of the elbow in his ribs. Landor.
A genus of orchidaceous plants including the lady's slipper.
A species of Cardamine (C. pratensis), or lady's smock. Itsleaves are used in salads. Also, the ragged robin (Lychnis Flos-cuculi).
The act of surprising, or state of being surprised; surprise.How to secure the lady from surprisal. Milton.Because death is uncertain, let us prevent its surprisal. Barrow.

A clog, or patten, having a very thick sole, or in some casesraised upon a stilt to a height of a foot or more. [Variously speltchioppine, chopin, etc.]Your ladyship is nearer to heaven than when I saw you last, by thealtitude of a chopine. Shak.
The quality or state of being ladylike.
A genus of cruciferous plants, containing the lady's-smock,cuckooflower, bitter cress, meadow cress, etc.
A man whose occupation is to make malt.
Much; great. [Written also muckle and mockle.] [Old Eng. &Scot.] "A man of mickle might." Spenser.
The man who manages a barge, or one of the crew of a barge.
Same as Eskimo.It is . . . an error to suppose that where an Esquimau can live, acivilized man can live also. McClintock.
A man who has authority to act, within certain limits, asmaster of the house; a steward; also, a chief minister or officer.
A man or boy habitually negligent of neathess and order; -- thecorrelative term to slattern, or slut. Pope.He became a confirmed sloven. Macaulay.
The husband of one's daughter; a man in his relationship to hiswife's parents.To take me as for thy son in lawe. Chaucer.

A parasite of man and of many domestic and wild animals,forming compound cysts or tumors (called hydatid cysts) in variousorgans, but especially in the liver and lungs, which often causedeath. It is the larval stage of the Tænia echinococcus, a smalltapeworm peculiar to the dog.
A man who carries a hod; a mason's tender.
A man born in Ireland or of the Irish race; an Hibernian.Irishman's hurricane (Naut.), a dead calm.-- Irishman's reef. (Naut.) See Irish reef, under Irish, a.
A man employed in placing supports of timber in a mine. Weale.

A chronic infectious disease of cattle and man due to thepresence of Actinomyces bovis. It causes local suppurating tumors,esp. about the jaw. Called also lumpy jaw or big jaw. --Ac`ti*no*my*cot"ic (#), a.
That part of the skeleton of the hand or forefoot between thecarpus and phalanges. In man it consists of five bones. See Illust.of Artiodactyla.
Master; sir; -- a title of a Turkish state official and man oflearning, especially one learned in the law.
A manifestation of God to man by actual appearance, usually asan incarnation.
A man engaged in rafting.
A half-castrated male animal.
The male reproductive apparatus in the lower, consisting of acell or other cavity in which spermatozoids are produced; -- calledalso spermary.-- An`ther*id"i*al, a.
A male hawk or eagle; a tiercelet. Chaucer.
A male lover.
A male Indian; a brave; -- correlative of squaw.

The male germ cell in animals and plants, the essential elementin fertilization; a microscopic animalcule-like particle, usuallyprovided with one or more cilia by which it is capable of activemotion. In animals, the familiar type is that of a small, more orless ovoid head, with a delicate threadlike cilium, or tail. Calledalso spermatozoön. In plants the more usual term is antherozoid.
A male red deer two years old; -- sometimes called brock.
A boy kept for unnatural purposes.

The manner or action of a wag; mischievous merriment; sportivetrick or gayety; good-humored sarcasm; pleasantry; jocularity; as,the waggery of a schoolboy. Locke.A drollery and lurking waggery of expression. W. Irving.
A boy who carries pots of ale, beer, etc.; a menial in a publichouse.
One of tree men united in public office or authority.

The son of Iapetus (one of the Titans) and Clymene, fabled bythe poets to have surpassed all mankind in knowledge, and to haveformed men of clay to whom he gave life by means of fire stolen fromheaven. Jupiter, being angry at this, sent Mercury to bind Prometheusto Mount Caucasus, where a vulture preyed upon his liver.

One who cuts purses for the sake of stealing them or theircontents (an act common when men wore purses fastened by a string totheir girdles); one who steals from the person; a pickpocketTo have an open ear, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is necessary fora cutpurse. Shak.
A beast; especially, a beast of burden. [Obs.]Fitter for juments than men to feed on. Burton.
A figure by which the conjunction is often repeated, as in thesentence, "We have ships and men and money and stores." Opposed toasyndeton.
A kind of traces with hooks and rings, with which men drag andmaneuver guns where horses can not be used.
An agent of a corporation, or of any body of men engaged in abusiness enterprise; an advocate or patron; an assignee.
The race of men native in Polynesia.

Priestly policy; the policy of a priesthood; esp., in an illsense, fraud or imposition in religious concerns; management bypriests to gain wealth and power by working upon the religiousmotives or credulity of others.It is better that men should be governed by priestcraft than byviolence. Macaulay.

A member of the Church of England, in the time of Charles II.,who adopted more liberal notions in respect to the authority,government, and doctrines of the church than generally prevailed.They were called "men of latitude;" and upon this, men of narrowthoughts fastened upon them the name of latitudinarians. Bp. Burnet.
A soft grass (Pennisetum typhoideum) found in all tropicalregions, used as food for men and cattle in Central Africa.
The state or condition of being well; welfare; happiness;prosperity; as, virtue is essential to the well-being of men or ofsociety.
a woman who is considered to be dangerously seductive
a woman who embroiders; a woman embroiderer.
A woman who is affectedly fastidious in language or taste; a woman who is over-refined: from the title of Molière's “Les précieuses ridicules.”
A woman who spins flax; hence, a common woman.
A woman; a young or unmarried woman; a girl.
A young woman who works.
A woman held unwillingly for purposes of prostitution.
Slang   A sexually promiscuous woman.
A woman regarded as cruel or malicious.
A woman prostitute hired by telephone.
A woman forced to serve as a prostitute for Japanese servicemen during World War II.
A woman belonging to the demimonde.
a malicious woman with a fierce temper
a woman forced into prostitution for Japanese servicemen during World War II
an ugly or ill-tempered woman
A woman separated from her husband by abandonment or prolonged absence; a woman living apart from her husband.
An old woman in general; especially, an ugly old woman; a hag.
an adulterous woman; a woman who has an ongoing extramarital sexual relationship with a man
an adulterous woman; a woman who has an ongoing extramarital sexual relationship with a man
A woman who has a jointure.
A woman who farms.
A woman who divines.
A woman who imposes upon or deceives others.
A woman who dictates or commands.
A woman who comforts.
A woman invested with authority to command.
A woman who knits.
A woman who caters.
A foolish or thoughtless young woman.
A woman who has taken a vow; a nun.
A woman who wails or mourns: used in the quotation with reference to professional mourners.
A woman who manages a boat.
Womanhood; the state of puberty in a woman.
A woman who renders professional aid to women in labor; a midwife.
A quarrelsome woman; a common scold.
A man or woman employed in sewing: in early use applied to those who sewed leather as well as cloth.
A woman who sews; a seamstress.
A woman who shoots; a female archer.
Archaic   Used formerly as a courtesy title before the surname of a married woman not of noble birth.

Any of various plants of the genus Sempervivum native to the Old World, especially S. tectorum, having a persistent basal rosette of fleshy leaves and a branching cluster of pinkish or purplish flowers. Also called live-forever, old-man-and-woman.
A woman aviator (in senses 1 or 3).
A woman who sells butter.
A woman who chides; a scold.
A nun; a woman who has vowed religious retirement. Also written cloisteress.
A woman who creates, produces, or constitutes.
A female detractor; a censorious woman.
A woman who nourishes or rears; a nurse.
A woman given to intrigue; a female intriguer.
A female gossip; a talkative woman.
A woman who cleaned wool.
A female knight; a woman of knightly character, or who is the wife of a knight.
A woman doorkeeper or porter, especially in a convent.
The leading woman soloist in an opera company.
The leading woman dancer in a ballet company.
A woman who has retired into seclusion for religious reasons.
a woman who is a mediator
A woman who sins; a female sinner.
A woman who ministers.
A woman who persecutes.
A woman who solicits.
A worthless woman; also, a worthless horse.
A woman who performs the duties of a tutor; an instructress.
A woman who is a votary.
A bride or wife; a married woman.
a girl or young woman crowned queen in the sports of May Day.
a young woman who is thought to have sex appeal
A lewd woman; a harlot.
a woman employed by a bar to act as a companion to men customers.
One who violates the chastity of a woman.
An Italian title of respect for a young woman, equivalent to Miss in English, Mademoiselle in French, etc.
A bluestocking; a literary woman.
A woman who is the head of a household or the mother of a family.
The American young woman of the 1890s as idealized in sketches by the American illustrator Charles Dana Gibson (1867-1944).
A woman who is the governor of a country, province, or colony, ruling as the representative of a sovereign.
Offensive   A woman who has remained single beyond the conventional age for marrying.
A voluptuous, alluring woman.
(Yiddish) an attractive, unconventional woman
a wife who is an attractive young woman; seldom the first wife of an affluent older man
(Yiddish) an attractive, unconventional woman
(Yiddish) an attractive, unconventional woman
a woman who is not married
a seductive woman who uses her sex appeal to exploit men
a woman whose husband has died in war
a woman who is White
a woman whose husband is dead especially one who has not remarried
a woman who engages in sexual intercourse for money
a woman who can be a successful wife and have a professional career at the same time
offensive term for an Asian woman
a girl or young woman who is unmarried
Informal   A young woman considered to have sex appeal.
An older woman, often one in a position of power or influence, who elicits the emotions usually reserved for a mother.
The foremost woman of a specified profession or art:  the first lady of the American theater.
A woman of great seductive charm who leads men into compromising or dangerous situations.
The primary woman of a household.
The chief unmarried woman attendant of a bride.
A woman who has never given birth.
Slang   A woman held to be antagonistic or overbearing.
an attractive young woman hired to attend parties and entertain men
a seductive woman who uses her sex appeal to exploit men
a young woman who holds up cards indicating the number of the next round at prize fights
a woman who engages in sexual intercourse for money
a young woman
a young woman
Informal   A woman who seeks money and expensive gifts from men.
a woman who was formerly a particular man's wife
a Japanese woman trained to entertain men with conversation and singing and dancing
a girl or young woman who is unmarried
a girl or young woman with whom a man is romantically involved
a woman who engages in sexual intercourse for money
a married woman; a man's partner in marriage
a woman who is old
a young unmarried woman who lives alone
a demanding woman who destroys men's confidence
a demanding woman who destroys men's confidence
a woman employed by a bar to act as a companion to men customers
a woman of advanced age
a woman who is Black
(Yiddish) an attractive, unconventional woman
a man who was formerly a certain woman's husband
alliterative term for girl (or woman)
A peeress in rank next after a countess and before a baroness. The title is usually held by the wife of a viscount, but in Great Britain it may be inherited by a woman in her own right.
A woman who practises obi. Also obea-woman, obeah-woman.
a single or unmarried woman; a woman who has never been married, or who has been divorced, or whose husband is dead.
A woman's cloak or mantle; also, a woman's gown.
Hence: A light or wanton woman; a woman inconstant in love. Called also light-of-love.
A female housekeeper; a woman who manages domestic affairs; a thirfty woman.
A French girl or young married woman of the lower class; more frequently, a young working woman who is fond of gallantry.
A woman, particularly an Indian woman.
A woman engaged in literary work; a woman whose profession is literature.
See connection, woman.
A woman's club; specifically, the first woman's club in America, organized in 1868.
A woman employed to dress, or to attend to the dressing or dresses of, others; a lady's-maid; a female dresser in a theater; a tiring-woman.
A Middle English form of woman.
An old spelling of woman.
Same as oyster-woman.
A woman who sold starch for the stiffening of the great ruffs worn in the sixteenth century. The starch-woman was a favorite go-between in intrigues. See the quotation.
A woman who bears a child for another person, often for pay, either through artificial insemination or by carrying until birth another woman's surgically implanted fertilized egg.
A woman; especially, a Dutch or German woman.
A woman of strong, masculine physique; a hardy, masculine woman disposed to rule her husband.
A young woman in attendance on a lady; a lady's-maid; a waiting-woman.
An old woman: a contemptuous term for any woman.
A woman who shows or confers favor; a woman who favors or supports.
A woman whose business it is to read aloud, as an attendant on a woman of rank; a female companion.
A woman who suckles another woman's child.
a woman who makes or sells butter; -- called also butter woman.

a baby conceived by fertilization that occurs outside the mother's body; the woman's ova are removed and mixed with sperm in a culture medium - if fertilization occurs the blastocyte is implanted in the woman's uterus
A woman's family name before she is married. Used of a surname that is replaced by a woman when she marries. Also called birth name.
A position for sexual intercourse in which a woman and man lie facing each other, with the woman on the bottom and the man on the top.

A woman who is devoted to literary or scholarly pursuits: "[Eva Le Gallienne] was ... a woman of letters who produced forcefully elegant translations of Ibsen and Hans Christian Andersen”  ( Margo Jefferson).

pregnancy test that involves injecting some of the woman's urine into an unmated female rabbit and later examining the ovaries of the rabbit; presence of corpora lutea indicates that the woman is pregnant
the act of sexual procreation between a man and a woman; the man's penis is inserted into the woman's vagina and excited until orgasm and ejaculation occur
the act of sexual procreation between a man and a woman; the man's penis is inserted into the woman's vagina and excited until orgasm and ejaculation occur
the act of sexual procreation between a man and a woman; the man's penis is inserted into the woman's vagina and excited until orgasm and ejaculation occur
the act of sexual procreation between a man and a woman; the man's penis is inserted into the woman's vagina and excited until orgasm and ejaculation occur

pregnancy test that involves injecting some of the woman's urine into an unmated female rabbit and later examining the ovaries of the rabbit; presence of corpora lutea indicates that the woman is pregnant
the act of sexual procreation between a man and a woman; the man's penis is inserted into the woman's vagina and excited until orgasm and ejaculation occur
the act of sexual procreation between a man and a woman; the man's penis is inserted into the woman's vagina and excited until orgasm and ejaculation occur
One wearing a waistcoat; esp., a woman wearing one uncovered, or thought fit for such a habit; hence, a loose woman; strumpet.
A woman who performs any work; especially, a woman skilled in needlework.
In antiquity, a priestess of Bacchus, or a woman who joined in the celebration of the festivals of Bacchus; a woman inspired with the bacchic frenzy. See mænad.
Any woman; specifically, a girl or young woman.

A peculiar domestic relation maintained between the sexes in certain quasi-religious and communistic communities in the United States, especially (formerly) among the Perfectionists of the Oneida Community, by which every man was virtually the husband of every woman, and every woman the wife of every man.
A woman of light behavior; a gill-flirt.
A light, giddy, or wanton girl or woman. See gill-flirt.
A woman who retails fish; a female fishmonger.
The lady of the May games; one of the characters in a morris dance; a May queen. Afterward, a grotesque character personated in sports and buffoonery by a man in woman's clothes.
My darling; -- an Irish term of endearment for a girl or woman.
A woman.
a married woman. See Covert, a., 3.
a married woman, who, by the custom of London, engages in business on her own account, inpendently of her husband.
A woman who acts as gunner.
A woman-eater.
A woman who fabricates.
A factor who is a woman.
a woman working on a farm; a farmeress.
A woman who invents.

An instrument of torture used in the middle ages, consisting of a box large enough to hold a person, often in the shape of a woman, and having multiple sharp spikes on the inside. Called also the iron maiden of Nuremberg.
A woman who fascinates.
A woman who is an exactor.
A woman affected with ennui.

In France, a name for a woman who is supported by her lovers, and devotes herself to idleness, show, and pleasure; -- so called from the church of Notre Dame de Lorette, in Paris, near which many of them resided.
A mild contagious viral disease, which may cause birth defects if contracted by a pregnant woman during early pregnancy; also called rubella.
Any old woman who is employed to guard a younger one; a governess.
A state of being released from coverture; freedom of a woman from the coverture of a husband.
A woman disseizes.
The act of endowing, or bestowing a marriage portion on a woman.
A woman entitled to dower.
A man and woman who are married to each other; a married couple.
A woman who attends to a dairy.
A woman who deciphers.
A woman who demands.
A woman of doubtful reputation or suspected character; an adventuress.
A woman's fitted jacket.
A woman who is an imitator.
A woman who makes laws.
A woman who sells fish; a fishwife.
A woman who competes.
A woman who conquers.
A woman who preserves from loss, injury, etc.
A woman who corrupts.
A woman whose husband is unfaithful to her.
A woman who cures.
A slovenly woman; a slattern; a draggle-tail.

A sale, gift, or delivery into the hand of another; especially, a sale, gift, delivery, or using which is the first of a series, and regarded as an omen for the rest; a first installment; an earnest; as the first money received for the sale of goods in the morning, the first money taken at a shop newly opened, the first present sent to a young woman on her wedding day, etc.
An Israelitish woman.
A woman that sells herbs.
A woman who tends a herd.
a framework of hoops for expanding the skirts of a woman's dress; -- called also hoop petticoat.
A woman employed in the kitchen.
An old dance, for two persons, being a kind of waltz, in which the woman made a high spring or bound.
A professed admirer of a married woman; a dangler about women.
Anything put together or made in a careless or slipshod way; hence, a sluttish or slipshod woman.
a woman hairdresser.
A small collar; specif., a woman's collar of lace, fur, or other fancy material.
The offspring of a mulatto woman and a negro; also, a mulatto.
A bad-tempered old woman.
A woman who holds a canonry in a conventual chapter.
A woman who carries a canteen for soldiers; a vivandière.
A female child, not a sister, reared with another child by the same person.
a youthful female person
a child who is female
your foster sister is a female who is not a daughter of your parents but who is raised by your parents
an extremely talented young female person
a youthful female person
an adult female person (as opposed to a man)
A female intruder.
A female hero; a heroine.
A female doctor.
A female doctor.
A female huckster.
A female contestant.
A shepherdess; a female herder.
A female who flatters.
A female guardian.
A female guide.
A female pope.
A female vassal or dependent.
A female mover: a stirrer of debate and strife.
A female rector or ruler; a governess.
A female singer.
A female archer.
A female hearer.
A female avenger.
A baker; properly, a female baker: as, “brewesteres and bakesteres,” Piers Plowman. In Scotland commonly written baxter: as, baxter wives.
A female builder.
A female butler.
A female commander.
A female champion.
A female singer.
A female constable; the wife of a constable.
A female cousin.
A female devourer.
A female dragon.
A female janitor; a janitress.
A female tyrant.
A female who is victorious; a victress.
A female saint.
A female soldier.
Either of a pair of slender ducts through which ova pass from the ovaries to the uterus in the female reproductive system of humans and higher mammals.
a female sovereign ruler
a female horse used for breeding
a female sovereign ruler
a female ass; also, a female of certain other animals.
A female ant of worker-like aspect due to the absence of wings and wing-muscles; an ergatoid female.
A female, or queen, ant of conspicuously larger stature than the normal female form of the species.
A female or queen ant of smaller stature than the typical female form of the species.
In ichthyology, congregation in unequal numbers of male and female fishes in spawning-time, the males being in excess and several males attending one female for a time and then changing for another.
In law, a female petitioner or female plaintiff in a bill in chancery.
The sex chromosome associated with female characteristics in mammals, occurring paired in the female and single in the male.
The character or state of being female; female nature.
The state of being female; female nature.
In embryology, the female nucleus; the female as distinguished from the male product of an original undifferentiated generative nucleus when this has become bisexed.
A technique used in animal breeding in which an embryo from a superovulated female animal is transferred to the uterus of a recipient female animal.
An organism having both male and female characteristics, especially an insect exhibiting a mixture of male and female tissues or sex organs.
the female reproductive cell; the female gamete
one having both male and female sexual characteristics and organs; at birth an unambiguous assignment of male or female cannot be made
female falcon especially a female peregrine falcon
female falcon especially a female peregrine falcon
a form of social organization in which a female is the family head and title is traced through the female line
a general term for female steroid sex hormones that are secreted by the ovary and responsible for typical female sexual characteristics
a female bee, especially the female of the honeybee. See Honeybee.
the female side in descent; in the female line; opposed to <ant>spear side</ant>.
In anc. art, a female figure in an attitude of prayer; a female adorant.

The resemblance of descendants to parents or ancestors considered reciprocally, or through the comparison of the descendants of male ancestors who are x and female ancestors who are y with those of male ancestors who are y and female ancestors who are x.

A chromosome that forms the distinctive characteristic between the male-producing and female-producing spermatozoa in certain insects (Hemiptera and Coleoptera). The idiochromosomes, which areusually smaller in the male-producing than in the female-producing forms, are supposed to be definitely correlated with the sexual characters.

A plate-gage, either male or female, used for checking the width of keys and key-seats, the female or receiving gage being notched the exact width of the key and its mate being the exact width required for the key way.
A female malefactor.
A female janitor.
A female figurant; esp., a ballet girl.
A female introducer.
The insertion of the male copulatory organ into the female in the process of coitus.
Pain occuring in the mamma or female breast, -- a form of neuralgia.
A female interlocutor.
A female messenger.
any wasp that constructs its nest, or brood cells, of hardened mud. The female fills the cells with insects or spiders, paralyzed by a sting, and thus provides food for its larvæ.
A female horn-maker.
A female emulator.
A female inspector.
A female Druid; a prophetess.
A female editor.
A female inhabitant.
A female reader.
A female lecturer.
A female dolphin.
A female impropriator.
A female improvvisatore.
a female demon who attacks children.
The milk-secreting organ of female mammals.
A female salmon.
A female child; a girl.
A female dancer.
A female defender.
A female deliverer.
A female demigod.
The business of a housewife; female domestic economy and skill.
A discharge of a white, yellowish, or greenish, viscid mucus, resulting from inflammation or irritation of the membrane lining the genital organs of the female; the whites.
The adult female of the mallee fowl (Leipoa ocellata). See leipoa.
A female martyr.
A female monitor.
A female cook.
A female servant or maid who dresses provisions and assists the cook.
A female creditor.
fertilization by the union of male and female gametes from different individuals of the same species.
A ventral canal or groove, in which the males of some diœcious trematodes carry the female. See Illust. of hæmatozoa.
An abnormal condition of certain animals, in which one side has the external characters of the male, and the other those of the female.
One of the branches bearing the female gonophores, in certain Siphonophora.
A female harper.

a European grouse (Tetrao tetrix), which inhabits heaths; -- called also black game, black grouse, heath poult, heath fowl, moor fowl. The male is called heath cock, and blackcock; the female, heath hen, and gray hen.

One of the arms of the male of most kinds of cephalopods, which is specially modified in various ways to effect the fertilization of the eggs. In a special sense, the greatly modified arm of Argonauta and allied genera, which, after receiving the spermatophores, becomes detached from the male, and attaches itself to the female for reproductive purposes.
A female hermit.
A female paramour; a mistress, concubine, or harlot.
A genus of scale insects including many species that feed on oaks. The adult female resembles a small gall.
A Dravidian of a group of tribes of Orissa, India, a section of whom were formerly noted for their cruel human sacrifices to the earth goddess, murder of female infants, and marriage by capture.

A bird of Madagascar (Leptosomus discolor), the only living type of a family allied to the rollers. It has a pair of loral plumes. The male is glossy green above, with metallic reflections; the female is spotted with brown and black.
A female doer or accomplisher.
A female citizen.
a female member of a clan.
One of a pair of organs used by the male for grasping the female among many of the Crustacea.
A female coadjutor or assistant.
a female student at a coeducational college or university.
A female heir who inherits with other heiresses; a joint heiress.
An organ of female insects, containing a cement to unite the ejected ova.
A female operator.
A female professional singer.
A female champion.
A female scold.

A species of flea (Tunga penetrans, formerly Pulex penetrans), common in the West Indies and South America, which often attacks the feet or any exposed part of the human body, and burrowing beneath the skin produces great irritation. When the female is allowed to remain and breed, troublesome sores result, which are sometimes dangerous. See jigger.
In ontogony, differentiation of male and female individuals from embryos having the same rudimentary sexual organs.
The female of the gorcock.
A female Greek.
The female of the falcon family of birds.
A form of parthenogenesis in which the virgin female gives birth to offspring of both sexes, as the so-called sexual generations in the Aphididæ and Cynipidæ.
A hybrid, the result of a cross between the male of the water buffalo and the female of the domesticated yak. The dzo are kept for beasts of burden and for the milk yielded by the cows.
The female aperture or vulva in arachnids.
In the Arachnida, the opening of the female genital organs; the epigyne.
The resemblance of certain male and female ants to workers, through a failure to develop the wings and their musculature.
A modified and infertile female flower of the fig-tree in which the fig-insect lives.
Either the male or the female pronucleus considered as an autonomous and persisting portion of the cleavage nucleus and the nuclei of the cells which arise by division from the fertilized egg.
The reproductive orifice of the female, in nemathelminths.
A member of a female religious order founded in 1534 by Countess Guastalla, and known as Angelicals (which see).
Rule or supremacy of the female, especially the alleged mother-right or matriarch ate of primitive human society.
Sexual selection through choice by the female.
One who favors or upholds female government.
In zoology, a female specimen taken as the type of a species.
In siphonophorans, a female blastostyle.
In Egypt, myth., a divinity, the female counterpart of Osiris, patroness of the cow: usually represented with the head and horns of a cow surmounted with the solar disk.
A female germ-cell or ovum.
In sporozoans, the mother-cell of a macrogamete or a female element: opposed to microgametocyte.
A female salmon.
The period of decline which follows the height of the period of sexual desire in female mammals.
The system of tracing name and kinship in the female line.
A female mule.
A female nabob: the wife of a nabob.
The female of the wild ass or onager.
A (hypothetical) somatic cell of a female organism, that is, one that produces ova as germ-cells.
A female parson.
In some macrurous crustaceans, a large membranous appendage attached to the base of the first pleopod in the male. In the female it is rudimentary.
A female buffoon. See Pierrot.
A common name for the primary oöcytes of the female and the primary spermatocytes of the male animal.
A woman; a female, unspecified. See quidam.
A South American lampyrid, probably a larviform female, luminous in patches along the sides, thus resembling a miniature railway-train at night.
A woman who regenerates; a female regenerator.
The attraction of male insects to a captive female.
A reproductive cell, either the sperm-cell of the male or the ovum of the female, or one of the cells from which they arise by division, such as the spermatogonia and the oögonia.
Viviparous parthenogenetic female organisms which give birth to males and to females which lay fertilized eggs. See normal parthenogenesis.
The enlarging of the female breasts at puberty.
That kind of parthenogenesis in which only female offspring are produced.
Hermaphrodism in which the individual is a female but has certain genital organs resembling those of the male.
A wingless parthenogenetic hibernating female of Chermes and allied aphidids.
A name given by Professor E. C. Ewart to a hybrid between a stallion and a female zebra.
A female tapster.
A female fallow-deer; a doe in the second year.
A female genoblast (which see): opposed to arsenoblast.
A peculiar structure on the ventral surface of the pereion in the female of some crustaceans.
A tirewoman; a female dresser, as in a theater.
A female Titan; a woman of surpassing size or power.
A female actor of tragedy; a tragic actress.
A female traitor; a traitress.
A female Turk. Disdainful Turkess.
An instrument producing a sound which resembles the cry of the female turkey, used as a decoy.
The hen or female of the turkey.
A female guardian.
In archaeology, an ancient Etruscan female head-dress of conical form; hence, any similar head-dress.
A woman who is an umpire; a female umpire.
A female who unfolds or discloses.
A female usurper.
The weaselduck; the female or young male of the smew
A female varlet; a waiting-woman. Richardson, Clarissa Harlowe, I. xxxi.
A female avenger.
A female vicar; the wife of a vicar.
A female vindicator.
A female visitor. Charlotte Brontë, Shirley, xxxiii.
A woman who makes or sells wafers; a female waferer.
A female warrior.
A female weaver.
The leading female character in the merrymakings at Whitsuntide.
A female author, designer, producer, or performer of any work.
The character or manner of a bluestocking; female pedantry.
A female juggler.
The state of being a maid or maiden; the state of an unmarried female; virginity.
A female mandarin.
An adherent of Marcellina, a female Gnostic of the second century, and a teacher of Gnosticism in Rome. Also Marcellinian.
Inheritance in the female line of descent.
The mesentery of the ovary; a fold of peritoneum holding the ovary in place, and representing in the female the mesorchium of the male.
An abscess of the female breast arising during lactation.
A female under age.
A female Moabite.
A female umpire or judge.
In zoology and anthropology, a mating with only one female or wife; the monogynous state: correlated with monandry.
A female mulatto.
A female teacher of music.
A female nail-maker.
A female goat.
A female neatherd; a neatress.
A female neatherd.
A female neighbor.
A familiar friend, whether male or female; a favorite or friend. See ingle.
A female nomenclator.
In Characeæ, the female sexual organ.
In surgery, the excision of the nymphæ; the circumcision of the female.
A female slave in the harems of the East, especially in that of the Sultan of Turkey.
A female offender.
In botany, one of those sporanges of Lycopodiaceæ which contain the larger or female spores.

A genus of small threadworms or nematoids of the family Ascaridæ, founded by Rudolphi in 1809; the pinworms. O. vermicularis infests the rectum; the female is half an inch loner, the male much smaller.
A female pander; a procuress.
A female leopard or panther.

A vestige of the urinary part of the Wolffian body in the female, corresponding to the organ of Giraldès in the male. It consists of scattered tubular remnants, situated in the broad ligament, nearer the uterus than is the parovarium.
A female pauper.
A woman who writes with a pen; a female writer; an authoress.
In mosses, an involucre inclosing both male and female organs. Compare perigone and perigynium.
A female perturber; a woman who perturbs or disturbs.

A name given to dandies in France in the reigns of Louis XIV. and Louis XV.; hence, in English literature, one who displays exaggeration in his dress and cultivates female society more or less obtrusively; a fop; a coxcomb.
A female incendiary. See pétroleur.
A female philosopher. Carlyle, Diderot.
A female philosopher.
Twins of opposite sex, boy and girl: so called because pigeons lay two eggs which normally hatch a pair of birds, a male and a female.
The female or young of the surf-scoter, a duck, Œdemia perspicillata.
A female parturient for the second or some subsequent time, or one who has borne two or more children.
In botany, the male sexual organ in Ascomycetes, which, either directly or by means of an outgrowth, conjugates with the oögonium, or female sexual organ.
A female porter or keeper of a gate.
A female postilion.
A supposed genus of isopods, founded on the female form of the genus Anceus.
A female preceptor or teacher.
A female president.
A female who produces.
A female progenitor or parent; an ancestress.
The female of the prongbuck.
Customary lewdness or prostitution in a female.
A female Quaker.
Craft or skill in policy on the part of a queen; kingcraft as practised by a female sovereign.
A female regent; a protectress of a kingdom.
A woman who sells at retail; a female huckster.
A female regulator; a directrix.
In law, a female relator or petitioner.
The female of the sagegrouse; also, this grouse without regard to sex.
A female satrap.
A female teacher of a school; a schoolmistress.
A manikin of the female pelvis and adjacent parts, used in teaching obstetrics.
A female deity of the ocean; a marine goddess.
A female searcher; an inventress.
A female servant, or maid-servant.
A female servant.
A female sexton.
Sex; also, either sex, male or female.
A female cutter or shaper of garments; a milliner or dressmaker.
A female sheriff.
A female sophist.
A woman who makes or mends shoes; a female cobbler.
A female fortune-teller.
The goosander or merganser, especially the female.
A female spectator or looker-on.
One of the parts into which the male or female pronucleus of an ovum may divide after fertilization.
A passage for the conveyance of sperm in the female of Echinorhynchus. See the quotation.
A hermaphroditic genital gland; a bisexual gonad; an ovispermary or ovotestis, which gives rise, simultaneously or successively, to male and female products. See cut under ovotestis.
A female helper.
A female who suggests.
A female supplicant or suitor.
A female supporter.
Sexual selection on the part of both male and female. Compare gyneclexis and andreclexis.
In zoology, an interval between periods in ‘heat’ when the female mammal has no sexual desire.
Sexual impotence, both male and female organs having lost their functions.
Loss of reproductive power in the female organs.
A female autocrat; an autocratrix.
A female ballet-dancer.
A female citizen or inhabitant.
A female coadministrator.
The production of male, female, and hermaphrodite flowers on different plants of the same species; triœcism.
The coexistence of male, female, and hermaphrodite flowers on the same individual plant.
An area of tissue surrounding the female urethra and running along the roof of the vagina, postulated to be erectile and to enhance sexual arousal.
A subspecies (Icterus galbula galbula) of the northern oriole in its eastern range, of which the male is bright orange and black and the female olive brown with white wing bars.
A poisonous New World spider (Latrodectus mactans), the female of which produces extremely toxic venom and has a black shiny body with red markings.
The sage grouse, especially the female.
A Eurasian game bird (Lyrurus tetrix) with black plumage and white wing markings in the male and brownish barred plumage in the female.
A New World bird (Piranga rubra) that catches insects in flight and whose plumage is rose-red in the adult male and, in the female, yellowish olive-green above and light brownish-orange below.
A large North American swallow (Progne subis) having glossy, blue-black plumage and, in the female, a light-colored breast.
The copulatory embrace of frogs and toads, during which the male fertilizes the eggs that are released by the female.
A method of female sterilization in which the fallopian tubes are surgically tied.
An interval of sexual inactivity between two periods of estrus in female mammals that breed cyclically.
Any of various sawflies of the family Siricidae, the female of which has a long stout ovipositor.
A cephalopod mollusk (Argonauta argo) with eight tentacles, the female of which inhabits a paper-thin shell that later acts as an egg case. Also called argonaut.
The female gametophyte of a seed plant, within which the embryo develops.
An external pouch or fold on the abdomen of most female marsupials, containing the mammary glands and in which the young continue to develop after leaving the uterus.
A female who arbitrates or judges.
A female arbiter; an arbitratrix.
A female architect.
A female sovereign who is independent and absolute; -- a title given to the empresses of Russia.
A female baker.
a bark louse (Ceroplastes cirripediformis) of the orange and quince trees in Florida. The female scale curiously resembles a sessile barnacle in form.
A female dancer in the East Indies.
An imperfect female calf, twinborn with a male, which is sterile as a result of exposure to masculinizing hormones.
In medicine, want of reproductive power in either sex; impotence of the male or sterility of the female. Also called agennesia.
A female albino.
The production in parthenogenesis of both male and female forms.
A female apostle.
The female organ in certain of the lower cryptogams, which after fertilization develops asci. Also called carpogonium and archicarp.
A female who asserts.
A female attendant. Fuller.
In ancient Greece, a female flute-player.
A female baboon.
A name of the female lumpfish, Cyclopterus lumpus.
A female salmon after spawning.
A female public dancer.
A female banker; a banker's wife.
A female barber; a barber's wife.
A kind of fur; the skin of the female deer.
A female blasphemer.
A mare of blooded breed; a female blood-horse.
The male of a kind of falcon, the female being designated bockeret or boccaret.
A female brewer.
A female centaur.
An itinerant female huckster.
A woman who buys and sells; a female trader.
The lower portion of the compass of both male and female voices, which most easily arouses sympathetic vibration in the cavity of the chest or thorax.
A female chief. Carver.
A female member of the church, specifically of the Anglican Church.
A female clairvoyant.
A fishermen's name for an old female seal.
An instrument for measuring the angle which the axis of the female pelvis makes with that of the body.
A female collector.
A female compounder.
In biology, the nucleus of a fecundated ovum, arising from the conjugation or fusion of a male with a female pronucleus.
A female consoler.
A female conspirator.
In Italy, a peasant woman; a female rustic.
A coheir; one who has an equal portion of the inheritance in lands of his or her ancestor with others; in English law, a female coheir, or a coheiress. See coparcenary.
A female calf. See free-martin.
A female creditor.
A female fortune-teller. See cunning-man.
A female dromedary. Also written deloul.
A female who deserts.
A female disenchanter.
A female disher.
A female dispenser.
A female elder.
The female of the stickleback.
A female who executes, accomplishes, or carries into effect. See executrix.
A female fautor or favorer; a patroness.
A female fellow. Compare fellow, 6.
One devoted to the female sex; a courter of women; a gallant.
The male plants of hemp, which, being soonest ripe, are picked out by hand from among the female, which are left to ripen their seed.
In mythology, a female deity or supernatural power having the form and attributes of a fish, either wholly or in part, as the Atargatis of the Philistines.
A female fox.
A female nourished or reared like an own daughter, though not such by birth.
A female seller of fruit.
In surgery, a morbid accumulation of milk at some point in the female breast, either an extravasation from a ruptured duct or contained in a dilated duct.
A female gambler.
A female general or commander.
The bisexual nucleus of an impregnated ovum, regarded as composed of a female part, feminonucleus, and of a male part, masculonucleus; a maritonucleus.
A moth, Ocneria Hypogymna dispar of naturalists, the sexes of which differ much in appearance, the male being blackish-brown and the female grayish-white: so called in England. Also called gipsy.
A female minstrel.
A female minstrel.
A female glutton.
A female gnome. See gnome, 1.
The female of the black grouse or blackcock.
The flowering or fruiting shoots of the female hemp-plant, Cannabis sativa, used in medicine, but chiefly for smoking.
A receptacle in the body of the male of some animals, as the diœcious trematodes, in which the female is contained; the gynecophoric canal, or canalis gynæcophorus.
The pistil or collective pistils of a flower; the female portion of a flower as a whole: correlative to andrœcium. Also gynœcium, gynœceum.
A female player on the harp.
A female performer on the harp.
The female heathbird; the hen of the black grouse.
A female heritor.

The name of a female character in Peele's play of “The Turkish Mahomet and the fair Hiren,” used allusively by Shakspere and other old dramatists in the bombast put into the mouths of various characters.
A female incumbent.
An heiress; a female who inherits or is entitled to inherit. Also inheritrix.
A female initiator.
A female inquisitor; an inquisitive or curious woman.
A female institutor; a foundress.
A female interlocutor.
A female jailer.
A pert girl: the female counterpart of jackanapes.
A female ass; a jenny.
A female keeper, custodian, or warden.
A kitchen-maid; a female scullion.
A female attendant upon a lady.
A female servant who works in a laundry.
An inflorescence consisting of a cuplike cluster of modified leaves enclosing a female flower and several male flowers, as in the poinsettia.

Inflammation of the female genital tract, especially of the fallopian tubes, caused by any of several microorganisms, chiefly chlamydia and gonococci, and characterized by severe abdominal pain, high fever, vaginal discharge, and in some cases destruction of tissue that can result in sterility.
Measurement of the dimensions and capacity of the pelvis, especially of the adult female pelvis.

A hormone produced by the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland that stimulates ovulation and the development of the corpus luteum in the female and the production of testosterone by the interstitial cells of the testis in the male.
The female gametophyte that arises from a megaspore of a heterosporous plant.
A large nonmotile female gamete or egg cell, formed in an oogonium and ready for fertilization.
A fertilized female cell or zygote, especially one with thick chitinous walls, developed from a fertilized oosphere.
A haploid cell that results from the meiotic division of an oocyte and becomes a female gamete or an ovum.
A female gamete, especially the larger of two gametes produced by an oogamous species.
A female reproductive structure in certain thallophytes, usually a rounded cell or sac containing one or more oospheres.
One of the segments of a tapeworm, containing both male and female reproductive organs.
Any of various dung beetles, especially of the genera Canthon and Phanaeus, that roll up balls of fresh dung, inside which the female deposits her eggs and on which the larvae feed.
A receptacle in the reproductive tracts of certain female invertebrates, especially insects, in which spermatozoa are received and stored until needed to fertilize the ova.
A capsule or compact mass of spermatozoa extruded by the males of certain invertebrates and primitive vertebrates and directly transferred to the reproductive parts of the female.
A sterile or otherwise sexually imperfect female calf born as the twin of a bull calf.
A test for cancer, especially of the female genital tract, in which a smear of exfoliated cells is specially stained and examined under a microscope for pathological changes. Also called Pap test.
The condensed, inactive X-chromosome found in the nuclei of somatic cells of most female mammals. Also called sex chromatin.

A subspecies (Icterus galbula bullockii) of the northern oriole in its western range, distinguished from the Baltimore oriole in the male by its orange cheeks and large white wing patches and in the female by its whiter belly.
Greek Mythology   A female sea monster who lived in a cave opposite Charybdis and devoured sailors.
Anatomy   Any of four folds of tissue of the female external genitalia.
The hybrid offspring of a male gibbon and a female siamang.

Either of two sand-dwelling brachyuran crabs (Persephona mediterranea or P. punctata) of the U.S. Atlantic coast, the Gulf of Mexico, and the West Indies, having a rounded body and, in the female, a purselike chamber for eggs.
The temporary or permanent association formed between a female and male animal during courtship and mating.
A female goat.
A female shaman or shamanistic healer, especially among Native American peoples.
A female of this species, used in falconry.
A male lanner, smaller than the female, used in falconry.
Any of various insects of the subfamily Lacciferinae, especially Laccifer lacca of southern Asia, the female of which secretes lac.
The female head or chief proponent, as of a movement or doctrine:  the high priestess of modern art.
The hybrid offspring of a male tiger and a female lion.
A pheromone, C19H38O, produced by female gypsy moths.
The female line or maternal branch of a family.
The nucleus of a fertilized egg immediately after the male and female nuclei have fused.
A hairlike terminal process forming the receptive part of the female reproductive structure in certain fungi or algae.
The capacity to function either as a male or a female.
A female helper or assistant.
A female admonitor.
breeding from a male and female from the same parentage.
breeding from a male and female of different lineage.
the note naturally used by the male bird to call the female. It is artificially applied by birdcatchers as a decoy.
A high-spirited, boisterous, or saucy girl.
a girl who is a member of the Girl Scouts
A member of the Girl Guides, a British organization of young women and girls founded in 1910.
an adolescent girl wearing bobby socks (common in the 1940s); -- sometimes used for any adolescent girl, especially one following the latest youthful fashion .
A young girl who carries flowers in a procession, especially at a wedding.
a girl who has grown up on a farm
a girl who is a member of Campfire Girls; for girls age 7-18
In Conservative and Reform Judaism, a Jewish girl of 12 or 13 years of age, considered an adult and responsible for her moral and religious duties.
a girl who works in a mill.
a girl who grew up in the tract housing in the San Fernando Valley
the girl chosen queen of a May Day festival
a girl with an attractive bust who wears tight sweaters
an adolescent girl wearing bobby socks (common in the 1940s)
A girl; esp., a great, awkward girl; a wench.
A light, giddy girl; a lascivious girl; a wanton.
See girl.
A member of the Girl Scouts, an organization of young women and girls, founded in the United States in 1912 on the plan of the Girl Guides, for character development and citizenship training.
A wanton, pert girl.
A gadding, flirting girl.
A rude, bold girl; a romp.
A girl; a lass; a wench.
Figuratively, a fair lass; a pretty girl.
A girl or young woman who works or is engaged in some useful manual employment.
A modest girl.
A handsome girl.
A “bonny lass”; a beautiful girl.
A wanton; a lascivious or light, giddy girl.
A thoughtless, giddy girl; a flirt-gill.
A girl; esp., a wanton; a gill.
A young girl: same as moppet, 2.
A country girl; a shepherdess; a sweetheart: a common name for such in old romances, pastoral poems, etc.
One who or that which pieces or patches; a boy or girl employed in a spinning-factory to join broken threads.
A rude, romping boy or girl; a wild, reckless fellow.
A giddy, volatile person; a madcap: generally said of a girl.
A school-girl.
A young girl who is still at school.
A young woman who tends a shop; a shop-girl.
A girl who is a member of the Campfire Boys and Girls.
A woman or girl whose welfare, training, or career is promoted by an influential person.

Partial or complete removal of the clitoris, prepuce, or labia of a girl or young woman, as practiced among certain cultures, especially in parts of Africa and western Asia. Also called clitoridectomy.
a homeless vagabond in the streets of a city, particularly and outcast boy or girl.
A girl or young woman employed in the mines of Cornwall, England.
A beautiful girl; a sweetheart.
A girl who performs the same duties as a cash-boy.
A girl brought up at a charity-school or on a charitable foundation.
A woman or girl who takes care of children during the day.
A wanton girl. Hye way to the Spyttell Hous. (Halliwell.)
A girl whose clothes hang loosely about her.
A giddy, frisking girl.
A sportive or wanton girl or woman.
A frolicsome young fellow; a roguish boy; a lively young girl.
A little girl.
A child, generally a girl a year or two old, carried on the back by professional beggar-women.
A girl who sells or delivers newspapers.
A girl who sells or delivers newspapers.
Used as a name in legal proceedings to designate an unknown or unidentified woman or girl.
A Filipino woman or girl.
A Mexican-American woman or girl. See Usage Notes at Chicano, Latina1.
An African-American woman or girl.
A girl or young woman employed in a business office to do odd jobs and errands.

An informal, exclusive system of mutual assistance and friendship through which women belonging to a particular group, such as the alumnae of a school, exchange favors and connections, as in politics or business: "Companies rely on an old-girl network whereby representatives use friends as contacts”  ( New York Times).
A teenage girl.
Used as a courtesy title in a German-speaking area before the name of an unmarried woman or girl.
A girl employed by a newspaper or broadcast news office to carry copy and run errands.
A teenage girl approaching her debut.
A girl who is in charge of the extra balls used in practice or those that are out of play, especially in baseball.
Christianity   A girl who is an altar server.
Informal   A girl Friday.
An Egyptian dancing girl; an Alma.
An amorous girl or woman; a wanton.
A girl; a lass.
A daughter; a girl.
a man who is the lover of a girl or young woman
The supposed wish of a girl or woman to have a penis, postulated by Sigmund Freud as a cause of feelings of inferiority and psychic conflict.
The main character in a picaresque novel when that character is a woman or girl.
a very pretty girl who works as a photographer's model
a preadolescent boy or girl (usually between 9 and 12 years of age)
a girl who is a servant
a girl who is a servant
sexual intercourse with a person (girl or boy) who has not reached the age of consent (even if both parties participate willingly)
Used as a courtesy title before the surname or full name of a woman or girl:  Ms. Doe; Ms. Jane Doe.
A girl or woman.
A girl; a wench.
A rude. wild girl; a tomboy.
a day boarder who is a girl
a girl employed to operate an elevator
a girl in a fairy tale who meets a wolf while going to visit her grandmother
the childhood of a girl
a professional dancing girl in India
a foreign girl serving as an au pair
(Judaism) an initiation ceremony marking the 12th birthday of a Jewish girl and signifying the beginning of religious responsibility
(Judaism) an initiation ceremony marking the 12th birthday of a Jewish girl and signifying the beginning of religious responsibility
United States illustrator remembered for his creation of the `Gibson girl' (1867-1944)
sexual intercourse with a person (girl or boy) who has not reached the age of consent (even if both parties participate willingly)
United States illustrator remembered for his creation of the `Gibson girl' (1867-1944)
a very pretty girl who works as a photographer's model
A word of endearment for a girl or woman.
A female professional dancer. See alma, ghawazee, nautch-girl, etc.
A wanton girl; a harlot.

A boy who is a member of the Campfire Boys and Girls, an organization for children aged 7 through 18 that strives to instill good values and teach practical skills. Before 1975, the organization was limited to girls.
a swelling over the knee, due to an enlargement of the bursa in the front of the kneepan; -- so called because frequently occurring in servant girls who work upon their knees.
Movements and evolutions performed in concert by a company of girls or ladies armed with fans.
One who ‘fusses’ over girls; a particularly active beau.
A rustic festival in which girls carry on their heads kits decorated with willow.
In Greek antiquity, a song sung by girls accompanied by the flute.
A porcelain wine-cup made by Chinese potters and decorated with figures of girls swinging.
A ribbon, braid, or the like made for the wear of country girls. Compare tawdry, a.
The livelong, Sedum Telephium: said to have been used by girls on midsummer eve to test their lovers' fidelity.
A society of women or girls who meet regularly to sew for the benefit of charitable or religious objects.
In Greek antiquity, a roll, knot, or tuft of hair on the top of the head, a mode practised especially by girls and young women.
In Brittany, one of the tiny fairies reputed to frequent druidical remains and to delight in beguiling young girls.
A member of an order of nuns of the Roman Catholic Church, founded in the early 16th century and devoted to the education of girls.
Chiefly British   A graduate of a public school for girls.
A close-fitting, often short T-shirt worn especially by young women and teenage girls.
masculinity in women (especially in girls and young women)
snug trousers ending at the calves; worn by women and girls
An overnight party in which guests, usually girls, wear nightclothes, socialize, and spend the night at a friend's home.
A private girls' school that stresses training in cultural subjects and social activities.
snug trousers ending at the calves; worn by women and girls
an organization of young women and girls founded in 1912 for character development and citizenship training
a decorative hinged clip that girls and women put in their hair to hold it in place
masculinity in women (especially in girls and young women)
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls
Chlorosis in girls.

a religious order founded in Dublin in the year 1827. Communities of the same name have since been established in various American cities. The duties of those belonging to the order are, to attend lying-in hospitals, to superintend the education of girls, and protect decent women out of employment, to visit prisoners and the sick, and to attend persons condemned to death.

an East Indian plant (Mantisia saltatoria) of the Ginger family, sometimes seen in hothouses. It has curious flowers which have some resemblance to a ballet dancer, whence the popular name. Called also dancing girls.

A white robe with a purple border, worn by a Roman boy before he was entitled to wear the toga virilis, or until about the completion of his fourteenth year, and by girls until their marriage. It was also worn by magistrates and priests.
a religious community of nuns, founded at Annecy, in Savoy, in 1610, and in 1808 established in the United States. In America these nuns are devoted to the education of girls.
word: the order of the visitation of our lady

definition: One of four young girls of noble birth who were chosen annually in ancient Athens to dwell on the Acropolis and attend the priestess of Athena Polias.

A game in which children, especially girls, stand in a row holding hands, and the outer one, still holding the one next, runs between the others under their uplifted hands, and is followed by the rest in turn. Also called thread and needle.
A small cape resem—bling a very broad collar, worn by women and girls in the first quarter of the nineteenth century.
A man who busies himself with affairs which properly belong to women.
Hatred of women; repugnance to the society of women.
An amended spelling of women.
The right of women to vote; exercise of the franchise by women.
difficulty in beginning the flow of urine; associated with prostate enlargement in men and with narrowing of the urethral opening in women; may be caused by emotional stress in either men or women
a compound found in women's urine during certain phases of the menstrual cycle and in the urine of pregnant women
a code that permits greater sexual freedom for men than for women (associated with the subordination of women)
In Roman antiquity, one of the two tunics commonly worn by both men and women, probably the outer tunic, though some archæologists have contended that it was the inner tunic of the women.
A waistcoat or kind of stays for women.
A man with a belief in the inferiority of women; one who believes in or practises male chavinism.
A muslin wrapper for the head and the lower part of the face, worn by Turkish and Armenian women when they go abroad.
The section of a hospital devoted to assisting women during childbirth and caring for them and their newborn infants until they are released to go home.
a jury of experienced women called to determine the question of pregnancy when set up in bar of execution, and for other cognate purposes.
a small dressy handbag, richly decorated, carried by women for formal occasions in the evening.
A short cloak or mantle worn by women.
One who makes dresses, cloaks, etc., for women; a dressmaker.
a boat race in which the crews are composed of a number of pairs, usually of men and women.

a standard or set of principles governing conduct, which is applied more stringently or differently to one group of people than to another; -- used especially of standards of sexual behavior that condemn behavior on the part of women that is condoned or not condemned when exhibited by men.
A kind of fabric for women's dresses.
A women who plays in comedy.
A kind of woolen material for women's skirts.
A square piece of linen used formerly by women instead of a cap; a kerchief.
a cap with wings, formerly worn by women.
Goat, seal, and other skins blacked on the grain side for women's shoes, etc.
That part of a large house, among the ancients, exclusively appropriated to women.
The branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women; same as gynecology.
A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
A thin silk or woolen goods, for women's dresses, woven in various styles and colors.
A supposed primitive state of society, in which all the women of a tribe were held in common.
A gallant who captivates the hearts of women.
The art or practice of captivating the hearts of women.
A thin worsted fabric for women's dresses.
A small spot on the front wall of the vagina in women, reported to be exceptionally able to produce high sexual excitement or orgasm when stimulated. Its existence is not universally accepted.
A similar jacket, usually ornamented, with or without sleeves, worn by women.
A gymnasium; esp. one for light physical exercise by women and children.
A garment for women, consisting of chemise and drawers united in one.
An under-garment, worn by women, usually covering the neck, shoulders, and breast.
A sentimental motion picture that appeals particularly to women.  See flick, n., movie.
A light, fine cotton or linen fabric of open texture for women's dresses.
A form of marriage in which a group of menare considered the husbands of a group of women.
In pathology, excessive hairiness, especially in women.
In Greek antiquity, a water-carrying; a group of women carrying water from a fountain: a subject often represented on the Greek hydria, or water-pots.
A garment, worn by Moro women, formed of a long piece of cloth, sewed together at the ends, which is wrapped about the body in various ways.
The women of a family or party. Compare womankind.
A light-weight fabric of silk and wool for women's wear.
A fine, sheer fabric of either silk or cotton, used for women's neckwear and for ruching.
A sort of sling or support by means of which the native Australian women carry their children on their backs.
A fabric for women's wear, having a satinarmure weave.
A room or ward in a hospital or other public institution where women are cared for during parturition.
A nose-ring worn by East Indian women as a badge of widowhood.

A closed carriage with two or four wheels, used by Roman women. Like similar medieval wagons it was arranged with entrance doors in the middle on both sides. Two or three pilenta are represented on the column of Theodosius at Constantinople.
In the Philippine Islands, a knot of hair held together by a comb, worn by Tagalog women.
In a Greek dwelling-house, a vestibule leading to the women's apartments: apparently, any open lobby, as between two piers or antæ.
A soft, silky flannel for women's dresses.
A loose gown (or a roll of cotton for the purpose) worn by native women in Egypt under the habara or cloak.
An ancient ornamented head-dress for women.
Apparently a heavy repped woolen goods, which was much used for women's winter gowns in Colonial days.
A very thin muslin, so open in texture as to be transparent, and often rather coarse in quality. It is used for women's evening dress, for widows' caps, etc.
A jacket worn by Eskimo men and women. See jumper.
A kerchief or veil of semi-transparent material, worn by women at the close of the eighteenth century.
A head-dress for women.
A stout twilled silk textile employed for women's dresses, and considered very durable.
A close linen or woolen cap, without lace, frill, or border, and with flaps covering the neck and part of the shoulders, worn chiefly by old women. Also toy.
A sash of silk, or silk and cotton, usually red, worn by women in Burma.
A leather prepared by oil-tawing without first removing the hair side, the flesh side being blackened in the usual way: used for women's boots and shoes.
A style of dressing women's hair in fashion about 1850, the hair being drawn back from the forehead, and forming a roll on the crown of the head.
Woolen cloth made from the wool of the vicugna. It is very soft, and is especially employed for women's clothes.
A full sleeve worn by women about tho middle of the seventeenth century.
A dress for the street; especially, at the present time, such a dress for women, as distinguished from a dinner-dress, an evening-dress, etc.
One who or that which makes widows by bereaving women of their husbands.
One who has an aversion to women in general; a misogynist.
One who kills women. See manqueller.
The exercise of the electoral franchise by women.
Woolen cloth woven with flowers and other patterns in a light matelassé silk. It is used for women's outer garments.
A small bag of some textile material, formerly carried by women, and used to contain their needlework. The term was often used for the reticule.

A basket used by women either to hold the implements for sewing, as needles, thread, scissors, or thimble, in which case the basket is small, or to hold partly made garments, articles needing repair, etc., for which use the basket is large and has a wide opening.
A box used by women to hold their materials for sewing and the needlework itself when not too bulky.
The veil worn by Moslem women in public—that is, when not in their own apartments.
A scolding bridle, an instrument formerly used for correcting scolding women. It was an iron frame surrounding the head and having a triangular piece entering the mouth of the scold.
A combination cloak and hood worn by women.
the gift or power of producing a glamour. The former is used figuratively, of the gift of fascination peculiar to women.
A milliner of the male sex; especially, one who undertakes the manufacture of women's bonnets, etc., employing others to do the work.
A loose outer garment worn by women.
A thin silk fabric used for linings, etc., in women's costume.
A loose gown or wrapper worn by women in the sixteenth century. It was used especially as an outer garment over the robe.
A woolen material for women's dresses and cloaks, usually having a narrow stripe.
A pickpocket who robs women only.
A Mohammedan inhabitant of Malabar in southwestern India, descended from Arabs who settled there and married native women.
A cap worn during the day, on other than ceremonial occasions; especially, a cap worn by women in the morning to cover and protect the hair.
A room used by the women of a family as a boudoir or sitting-room, and supposed to be occupied only before dinner.
A loose full gown worn by women: so named from its general resemblance to that considered characteristic of “Mother Hubbard” in the rimes of “Mother Goose.”
A brooch of jet or other suitable material, worn by women as a sign of mourning.
A small muff worn over the wrist; a wristband of fur or worsted worn by women.
Excessive fondness for women.
A muslin of the finest quality, thin, soft, and transparent, used for women's dresses and the like. The name is usually given to the English and other imitations of mull. See mull.
A neck-handkerchief, specifically that worn by women in the eighteenth century.
The servitude, bondage, or villeinage of women.
A long close-fitting coat for women's outdoor wear, usually made of broadcloth.
A part of women's dress, probably a veil, worn in the latter part of the fifteenth century.
Numbness of the extremities coming on at night: it occurs sometimes in women at the menopause.
A defense for the nipple worn by nursing women.
One of several varieties of bunting used for women's gowns.
An untwilled woolen fabric, very soft, fine, and thin, used by women for veils, and also for dresses, etc.
A muslin of great fineness and translucency, used for women's dresses. It is sold both plain and figured with printed flowers, etc.
A smooth, strong, rich silk, originally manufactured at Padua, used for garments of both women and men in the eighteenth century; also, a garment made of this material.
A kind of straw bonnet for women, introduced about 1850.
In the costume of the seventeenth century, a partial wig; a front of curls, or the like, worn by women when not in full dress.
A cluster of curls or loose locks of hair on the temple: a style of dressing women's hair in the early part of the eighteenth century.
A lover of women: the opposite of misogynist.
In civil and Scots law, the crime of stealing men, women, or children, formerly punishable with death.
In textile fabrics, a pattern of round dots or spots, especially in printed stuffs for women's wear.
A knitted jacket worn by women.
A loose gown formerly worn by men and women to protect their clothes when having the hair powdered; a dressing-gown.
A kind of lasting of which clergymen's gowns were once made, now rarely used except for the uppers of women's shoes. Also called everlasting.
A head-dress for women, derived from the East, probably the Levant, and adopted in Spain in the thirteenth century. It was practically an upright and nearly cylindrical hat.
A cap worn by women in the eighteenth century, apparently a form of the mob-cap: the name is taken from Ranelagh, a place of fashionable resort near Dublin.

A piece of dress among the ancient Romans, consisting of a mantle, smaller and shorter than the pallium, and having a cowl or hood for the head attached to it. It was worn especially by women, particularly as a morning garment, and by mimes on the stage.
A hood used by women in the eighteenth century, and perhaps earlier, when traveling or exposed to the weather, the use of it depending on the style of head-dress or coiffure in fashion of the time.
A separate skirt fastened around the waist over the other dress, worn by women in riding.
